data.title: Cannot launch vscode-languageserver-node-example server under debugger
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win 10 14393.953
- Node version 6.9.4

**Steps to Reproduce:**

```
1. git clone https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node-example 
2. cd vscode-languageserver-node-example\src\client
3. npm install
4. npm build
4. cd ..\server
5. npm install
6. npm build
7. code .
8. F5
```

Error: `Cannot connect to runtime via 'legacy' protocol; consider using 'inspector' protocol (timeout after 10000 ms).`

Incidentally, I tried to enable tracing - according to the docs here: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/node-debugging there should be a `trace` attribute that I can add to my configuration, which I can set to `all` to enable verbose debugging. That fails as well, with the error: `Property trace is not allowed`

The server does run fine if I launch it via the client project. But I cannot debug the server code. This used to work ... recently - in the past month or so for me. But no longer, and on multiple machines.

data.title: [SCM] Ability to edit while commit is in process is misleading

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
*This issue is very noticeable if you have git hooks which take a little time to execute*

- VSCode Version: 1.11-insider
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Stage some files, make a commit
2. While the commit is in progress, the commit message text box is enabled, which allows me to change the message - but this message doesn't get committed.
3. While the commit is in progress, I can change the staged files (add/remove more files), which do get committed.

Now, I'm not sure exactly what the *intended* behaviour is, but as I see it:
1. The message should not be editable, or if it is editable, the final message should be applied to the commit.
2. The staged file list should not be editable, because if it is, then there is a problem since the list of files passed to the pre-commit hook, and the list of files committed can be different. This can cause potential bugs in projects if they rely on commit-hook to be a source of truth.

For a reference, Git-GUI disables any action while a commit is in progress.

data.title: feature request: continue press ctrl+shift+i to select line up
data.body:
currently when press ctrl+i several times vscode will select line below. 
what about press ctrl+shift+i to select line up


analysis: ctrl+i bind to expandLineSelection, this command will select current line and move cursor to the first column of next line, 
we can implement a comand expandLineSelectionUp that select current line and move cursor to the **previous** line.

- OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Click Extensions

```
Cannot read property 'call' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'call' of undefined,
    at e.onCommonRequest (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:7:5404),
    at e.onMessage (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:7:5241),
    at /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:7:5034,

    at Socket.<anonymous> (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/code/node/sharedProcessMain.js:7:11558),
    at emitOne (events.js:96:13),    at Socket.emit (events.js:188:7),
```

data.title: Find in Files partially broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: none
---

I'm suddenly unable to "Find in Files" inside `*.ts` and `*.tsx` files. Searching in other file types works fine.

This behavior survives reboots and survives restarting the Windows search service.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ctrl+Shift+F to open Find in Files dialog
2. Search options: unselect all three options (match case, whole word, use regexp)
3. Files to include: one of
      a) `*.ts,*.tsx`
      b) `*.js,*.md`
      c) `*.*`
4. Files to exclude: blank
5. Files excluded through settings: for me this shows
        `**/.git, **/.svn, **/.hg, **/.DS_Store, **/node_modules, **/bower_components`
6. Search text: some bit of text present in many files (I've used just the letter e)

Expected behavior:

1. See list of all files and lines of text containing the indicated search term

Actual behavior:

1. When searching `*.ts,*.tsx` the results are empty even though there are many `*.ts` and `*.tsx` files matching the search condition
2. When searching `*.js,*.md` the results are as expected, all `*.js` and `*.md` files matching the search conditions
3. When searching `*.*` the results include `*.js,*.md`, and `*.json` files but no `*.ts` or `*.tsx` files

Additional behavior notes:

1. The explorer and text editor views show the `*.ts` and `*.tsx` files in the project. 

2. The typescript project builds correctly when using Ctrl-Shift-B to build.

3. Immediately before this condition started, Outlook reported a toast message something like "Windows search did not correctly close the message file" (It disappeared from the screen before I could write it down precisely). I don't know if that message is related or if it is whether it is a root cause or a symptom of some other root cause impacting both Outlook and Code. Rebooting the machine and restarting the Windows search service resolved the outlook issue but did not resolve the code issue.

4. This search condition started today. For the past month I have been receiving error messages every time I launch Code that there is a "Version Mismatch global tsc 2.1.5 != VS Code's language service 2.2.1" I have repeatedly read the link embedded in that message and have NO IDEA how to resolve that issue because the link doesn't tell me what to change or where (though I believe the current text may well be helpful to someone who already knows how to fix the issue and merely needs a reminder of what files are involved). I doubt this search issue is related to the version issue, but I mention it, and I sincerely hope that you will please also fix the page that is linked to by that error message to have a bulleted list of "step 1 do this step 2 do this step 3 do this" instructions on how to make that error message go away because it's incredibly frustrating to be completely powerless to fix the error even after repeatedly reading your "help text." But again, based on that error being present for a month prior to the search issue I doubt it's a root cause of this search issue.

[edited to fix markup that was hiding `*` characters in text]

data.title: Use a stable sort when sorting Edits
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

There was a conversation on how to insert multiple text changes that all have the same starting position over in https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/14441. To specify the order explicitly, we thought the ordering of edits in a change should work as a tiebreakers (ie: use a stable sort when ordering the edits).

Can the vscode side respect this property when applying changes? After a bit of debugging, it looks like the necessary change would be to replace https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/common/services/bulkEdit.ts#L98 with a stable sort.

I would put up a PR except that I was unable to find an existing stable sort and I'm unsure if there's some pattern you'd prefer to use for an implementation.

If it helps, I'll later edit this with an explicit repro (the case I'm running into is currently dependent on a change I've yet to merge into https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript).

data.title: Feature Request: Configure VSC to stop auto-restore and build of .NET Core projects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win10 Pro

I use VSC to work on documentation projects that include .NET Core samples. When I open folders to work on sample files, these sample projects should **not** be restored/built. VSC keeps creating `obj` and `bin` folders automatically against my wishes, and I need to then manually delete them from the samples.

I'm aware of ...
```json
"csharp.suppressDotnetInstallWarning": true,
"csharp.suppressDotnetRestoreNotification": true,
```
... but those don't actually prevent the auto-restore/build behavior. Looking at the [workspace settings doc](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/userandworkspace), I don't see a way to disable auto-restore/auto-build for .NET Core projects, so I'm asking if you would consider adding such a workspace setting if such a setting doesn't already exist (undocumented).

data.title: Evaluating something collapses expanded items in variables pane
data.body:
- Start a debug session, hit a breakpoint
- Expand something in the variables pane
- Eval something in the console

The expanded item collapses. I think we re-request variables after evaluating something, but it would be great to match up the expanded items from before, to keep them expanded. Then, could even keep them expanded while stepping. Chrome devtools seems to do this.

data.title: Feature request to enable CodeLens to appear above decorators (TypeScript)
data.body:
This is how CodeLens currently looks when it appears on a property with decorators applied (same happens with methods and classes):

![codelens-decorators](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13468659/23973361/15d6e5f6-09d6-11e7-939b-84fc8cf2c2ad.png)

(TypeScript)

It would be nice to either have CodeLens annotations above decorators, or have a setting to enable this, as it's a bit hard to follow the code right now. Moving the decorator to the same line where the property/method declaration is is certainly better for now, but it's not always feasible.

data.title: Set default save location to that of most recent file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.10.2`
- OS Version: `macOS 10.12.2`

This is a feature request from Sublime Text. I have a fairly well nested project and anytime I go to save a new file, it always defaults to project root (which makes sense). However, if I'm trying to save `project/assets/templates/category/file.html` and `project/assets/static/styles/category/file.scss` it can get really tedious to get those save locations. 

In ST, when you're saving a new file, the mac saver dialog defaults to the location of the most recently open file. This is great because you can open an existing file in the directory you want, hit the new tab, and `save` puts it right where you want it to be. 

Right now, my workaround is to use "copy path" in the side bar and `touch` in the integrated terminal to create the file I need, then paste in. 

This would be a super useful feature for very complex file structures in projects!

data.title: Opening strings such as template literals in a new buffer, synced with original
data.body:
There are many issues asking for language support in embedded strings, such as using HTML in ES6 template literals. It seems that it will take considerable effort to get done, and are not yet on the roadmap as far as I know.

As an intermediate solution, could VS Code facilitate opening embedded strings (when in TypeScript, for example) on the side buffer and syncing it with the original string, so that one could use any language infrastructure that is already automatically in place today for that buffer (highlighting HTML, SQL, etc)? Copying strings across buffers is of course possible already (and works great!) but it is not really usable until selecting the string and keeping it in sync is mostly automatic. Maybe they could be "portals" or something. Alternatively one could use some kind of narrowing to the part in question, but it is imperative that language services would work properly for the narrowed part as they do now for a separate buffer. 

**Later edit**: Published an extension that implements this, works great: [Template Literal Editor for VS Code](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=plievone.vscode-template-literal-editor). Will try to remember to keep it updated when Extension API offers new possibilities (scroll and cursor sync, document tiles, etc).

data.title: Output in terminal ignores line/column numbers
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 (Commit 8076a19f)
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise v1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run a js/ts file from terminal (press `ctrl-'`) (in my case I ran using `ts-node myfile.ts`)
2. Throw an error
3. Click on one of the call stack lines

Expected

Actual

When I hover over the line of the call stack, you can see that only the file is highlighted, not the line or column number (see underlined file):

data.title: Problem executing shell commands in build task
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions: C#, Docker

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.0|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.12|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. download github desktop (to get git and powershell git tools)
1. update your powershell profile to have the same tools that would be used by github desktop
```
Write-Host "Setting up GitHub Environment"
. (Resolve-Path "$env:LOCALAPPDATA\GitHub\shell.ps1")

Write-Host "Setting up Posh-Git"
. (Resolve-Path "$env:github_posh_git\profile.example.ps1")
# Chocolatey profile
$ChocolateyProfile = "$env:ChocolateyInstall\helpers\chocolateyProfile.psm1"
if (Test-Path($ChocolateyProfile)) {
  Import-Module "$ChocolateyProfile"
}
```
3. set up a .NET Framework project with vs code build task
4. ensure build task uses some tools only provided in the user's powershell profile (e.g., git in this case)
5. use vs code to build the project and see that it doesn't work (my guess is that it's either not respecting the configured integrated shell or not using the user's profile for the shell)
